description: Section-by-section structure templates for Renewal Weekly

openingHook.name: Opening Hook
structure: Seasonal/timely observation
Connection to reader or gratitude
Brief sign-off: Thanks for being here
rules: NEVER mention stem cells or medical content
DO NOT end with sign-off (it comes after the teasers)
openingHook.example: It's almost Thanksgiving, and perhaps unsurprisingly, we're feeling thankful today. Thankful for you, dear reader, as well as for having the opportunity each week to share the latest healthcare analyses with you. Thanks for being here, and we hope you continue to stay tuned for more.

inTodaysEdition.name: In Today's Edition
structure: Emoji + short teaser phrase for lead story
Emoji + short teaser phrase for research
Emoji + short teaser phrase for deep dive or stat
Emoji + short teaser phrase for another topic
rules: Make readers curious to scroll down

leadStory.name: Lead Story

good: Stem Cells Just Did What Doctors Said Was Impossible
The Anti-Inflammatory Shopping List You Actually Need
bad: You Won't Believe What Scientists Discovered

structure: Para 1: Hook - 'For [X million] Americans with [condition], the prognosis has always been the same: [limitation].'
Para 2: Pivot - 'That changed this week.'
Para 3: **Here's what happened:** Key findings, 2-3 sentences, one {{LINK}}
Para 4: **Why this matters now:** What's different, 2 sentences
Para 5: **What's next:** Timeline, next steps, 1-2 sentences
Para 6: Quote from researcher, 1 sentence
Para 7: **The zoom out:** Bigger picture, one {{LINK}}
leadStory.sources: PRIORITIZE mainstream health publications (CNN Health, NYT, WebMD, Healthline)
rules: Stories should have wide appeal (affecting millions)
AVOID niche scientific journal articles (save for Research Roundup)
Every sentence must earn its place

researchRoundup.name: Research Roundup

headlines.example: New MS Treatment Reverses Nerve Damage

structure: Line 1: Headline (8 words max)
Para 1: Hook - 'If you or someone you love has [condition]...'
Para 2: Key findings, 2 sentences, include {{LINK}}
Para 3: **What you should know:** Practical info (cost, availability)
Para 4: **The catch:** Honest limitation
Para 5: **Bottom line:** Actionable next step
researchRoundup.sources: PRIORITIZE scientific journals (Nature, Cell, Science, NEJM, Lancet, JAMA)
rules: This is where niche research goes
Always include cost range if applicable

secondaryStories.name: On Our Radar

perStory: Bold lead: Complete thought that could stand alone

goodBoldLeads: Stanford just made stem cell transplants safer‚Äîwithout chemo.
Type 1 diabetes was cured in mice. Humans might be next.
MSC trials are up 37% in 2025‚Äîand investment is following.
rules: Each story from different topic area
Bold lead should work as standalone statement

deepDive.name: Deep Dive
structure: Contrarian opening: Challenge common assumption
Evidence: What research actually shows
**What to add:** Bulleted list with specifics
**What to cut:** Bulleted list
**The connection to stem cells:** How this relates to regenerative health
openingPatterns: The [industry] wants you to believe [common belief]. [Source] disagrees.
You've probably heard [common advice]. Here's what actually works.

statSection.name: Stat of the Week
structure: **Big number** (prominently displayed)
*What it represents* (italicized subtitle)
Para 1: Context and scale comparison
**Why it matters for you:** Personal relevance
**Translation:** Plain English meaning

example.subtitle: where the regenerative medicine market is headed by 2032
example.content: That's not a typo. The regenerative medicine market is projected to grow from $48 billion today to over $400 billion in the next seven years.

thePulse.name: The Pulse
thePulse.good: Takeda launched a new autologous stem cell therapy for cartilage regeneration in Japan this month
thePulse.bad: In exciting news, Takeda has announced the launch of an innovative new therapy... (too wordy)

worthKnowing.name: Worth Knowing
types: Awareness: Upcoming health event with date and action
Guide: '5 Red Flags When Choosing...' type tips
Resource: Helpful tool with real URL

example: (1) They claim to treat everything with the same cells.
(2) They use 'amniotic' products without explaining contents.
(3) They rely entirely on testimonials instead of data.
(4) They're not FDA-compliant or won't discuss it.
(5) They offer IV stem cell treatments (currently forbidden).

recommendations.name: RECS
rules: Each must have real, working URL
